themes.label: Honorific Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The inscription honors a Hierophant from Paiania, detailing his extensive career and noble lineage as recognized by the Council of the Areopagus, the Council of the 500, and the People of Athens.

themes.label: Votive Dedications
themes.rationale: The text concludes with a dedicatory formula (anetheken), indicating the monument was set up as a religious offering in gratitude for the subject's piety.

themes.label: Cursus Honorum
themes.rationale: The inscription provides a detailed cursus honorum (career summary) of civic and religious offices held by the subject and his ancestors, including Eponymous Archon, Strategos, and Herald.

themes.label: Agonistic / Victory Inscriptions
themes.rationale: The text explicitly mentions the subject's role as an Agonothete (festival organizer) for the Panathenaic Games.

themes.label: Statue Base
themes.rationale: The honorific nature, the mention of 'setting up' (anetheken), and the physical context of such inscriptions at Eleusis suggest this text was inscribed on a statue base.

themes.label: Marble
themes.rationale: Marble was the standard material for monumental honorific inscriptions in Roman-era Attica and the sanctuary of Eleusis.

persons.name: Flavius (Hierophant of Paiania)
persons.role: Hierophant and subject of the inscription

persons.name: Flavius Alcibiades
persons.role: Father of the subject and former Eponymous Archon

persons.name: Flavius Leosthenes
persons.role: Paternal ancestor and former Eponymous Archon

persons.name: Lucius Aurelius Verus
persons.role: Roman Emperor initiated into the Mysteries by the subject

rationale: This inscription from Eleusis honors a prominent Hierophant from the deme of Paiania and the Eumolpidae clan. It serves as a record of his distinguished career, holding major Athenian offices such as Eponymous Archon, Strategos over the Hoplites, and Herald of the Areopagus. Crucially, it documents his role in the Eleusinian Mysteries, specifically his initiation of the Emperor Lucius Verus. The text also traces his elite lineage through several generations of Athenian officials and mentions his relationship with the Emperors Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
